Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dibble is a versatile website and platform that hosts collaborative, user-friendly, participatory data collection and analysis projects. Dibble projects start with users' own questions, engaging users by building on their curiosity, goals and interests. While collecting, analyzing, and visualizing data within Dibble, users are also engaging in critical STEM-based skills. Dibble differs from other online project development efforts in at least three critical respects. First, Dibble will be a user-friendly platform that facilitates the creation of projects by participants themselves, based on their unique interests. Second, while all projects will include STEM processes and skills, the project content will not be predetermined and can include content from a range of disciplines and fields lending itself to better engage and retain the interest of individuals who aren't already predisposed to STEM. Third, Dibble will be more impactful on learning than typical citizen science projects because users' actions will be linked to regular, ongoing feedback from moderators and topical experts with a focus on guiding project development, recognizing user contributions, and further engagement in project content. By virtue of being web-based, Dibble will be broadly accessible. With future development supported by a range of collaborative partners and a well-designed dissemination and viral marketing plan, it has the potential for widespread, enduring growth, with the goal of creating a more STEM-literate society.

Dibble will take advantage of and contribute to the growing capabilities of digital technology, social networking, and mobile devices to explore new avenues for reaching user audiences. Typically, in order for audiences to take advantage of informal learning opportunities, they must have a predisposition to go to an informal learning setting to pursue an interest, hobby or find the answer to meet an acute need. Dibble seeks to reach those who aren't entering those typical informal learning settings by supporting the creation of STEM learning opportunities in projects that grow directly from the users' interests. Additionally, Dibble creates an opportunity to build on new understandings in the field of computer-supported collaborative learning as well as emerging understandings in participatory urbanism and participatory learning. Dibble operationalizes these theories in a way that capitalizes on new media, technology, design, STEM and STEM education to develop new ways to engage the public in STEM as well as new approaches to data collection and visualization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A “dibble” is a tool used in gardening to make space in the soil to plant seeds. Dibble – the learning platform and app - will similarly plant the seeds of interest and participation in the scientific process by supporting learners in asking their own questions, collecting and visualizing data in charts and graphs, and receiving feedback from teachers, peers, and science experts. The major goals of the I-Corps L project were to 1) Interview a range of potential Dibble customers and users to determine their need for a tool like Dibble, 2) Identify which of these groups of would be most likely to purchase, and/or financially support Dibble, and 3) Develop a preliminary business model for Dibble.

 

The I-Corps L team conducted 101 interviews with business professionals, informal STEM program educators, K-12 educators, university instructors, teacher professional development providers, curriculum developers, scientists, youth learners, adult learners, parents, and science museum employees (program instructors, program managers, executives, and other staff).  The interviews revealed that science museums, in particular, needed a tool like Dibble to help them support science learning through their out-of-school programs and provide their visitors with a connection to their exhibits and collections beyond the physical walls of the museum.

 

Our interviews also gathered information about how to design Dibble so that learners would enjoy using it. We learned that Dibble should be designed with the following features in mind: 1) welcoming to learners with a wide range of knowledge and prior experience, 2) allowing competition and achievement; 3) encouraging discovery and curiosity; 4) providing entertainment; and 5) encouraging social interaction. In addition, we learned that users would enjoy Dibble the most if projects they created were related to a real-world issue that they cared about. 

 

With this information, the team worked with a software company to create “early mockups” or designs for what the different views and screens of the app might look like. In future work, we plan to work with museums to customize these basic designs for specific projects related to their educational programs and exhibits. In July, 2017, the team received funding to work with a nature museum to develop and test a “working prototype” of two different Dibble investigations. Over the next year, we will interview students to gather information on Dibble’s usability and to support the next phase of design. The goal is to find the right balance between user-directed navigation, to ensure users are motivated and confident in their activity, and built-in guiding and supporting features.

 

There is a deep need to support scientific literacy among US citizens. Research shows that digital media (social networking, mobile devices, and the Web) can be used to make science learning more relevant and learner-centered, providing opportunities for “anytime, anywhere” learning. Dibble takes advantage of these technologies, providing new ways to involve learners of all ages in the scientific process. At the same time, the use of technology is only part of the solution - educators, mentors, and peers are critical in guiding their learning. Applying Dibble within museum education programs can provide a bridge to helping youth use scientific practices in meaningful, learner-directed activities. While science museums are the most promising initial customer segment, Dibble has the potential to grow into a learning tool used in many different environments, both in and outside of school.
